SCHEME FOR THE RECIPROCAL RECOGNITION

OF TESTS AND INSPECTIONS CARRIED OUT

ON SHIPS' EQUIPMENT

The purpose of this Scheme is to facilitate trade in ships' equipment by allowing certain tests and inspections required by a Participating Authority of the importing country to be carried out by another Participating Authority of the exporting country.

Explanation of terms

1. For the purpose of this Scheme: 

  

     (a)  »SHIPS« EQUIPMENT' means any equipment, including  

          life-saving appliances and fire-extinguishing equipment,  

          which is subject to the requirements and approval of or  

          acceptance by a Participating Authority;  

     (b)  »PARTICIPATING AUTHORITY« means the administration in a  

          country which is competent to approve or accept ships'  

          equipment in relation to national regulations and which  

          participates in this Scheme. Participating Authorities are  

          listed in the Appendix.

Submission of designs and specifications

2. A person wishing to export ships' equipment or a person authorized by him shall: 

  

     (a)  under reference to this Scheme, forward to the Participating  

          Authority whose approval or acceptance he wishes to obtain,  

          in accordance with its required procedures, designs and  

          specifications in respect of that equipment together with  

          details of certifications by the authorities of other  

          countries;  

           and  

     (b)  specify the Participating Authority intended to undertake  

          the tests and inspections.

Approval of designs and specifications; inspections and tests (* 1)

3. The Participating Authority whose approval or acceptance has been reguested shall, without undue delay, declare to the Participating Authority specified in accordance with paragraph 2(b), if it so finds, that the designs and specifications submitted to it are in accordance with its regulations or are otherwise acceptable to it and shall at the same time request the latter Participating Authority to undertake, on its behalf, such of the following operations as it finds appropriate to the facilities of that authority: 

  

     (a)  inspection of the production facilities of the manufacturer;  

     (b)  surveillance of production;  

     (c)  inspection and tests of the prototype;  

     (d)  issuance of reports, certificates and other documentary  

          material.

Reports, certificates and other documentary material

4. The reports, certificates and other documentary material referred to in paragraph 3(d) shall be submitted by the Participating Authority which has carried out the operations to which they relate, to the Participating Authority on whose behalf they have been undertaken. Upon receipt of these reports, certificates and other documentary material the latter Participating Authority shall, if satisfied, grant without undue delay such final approval of the ships' equipment to which they relate as is laid down in its regulations or otherwise indicate its acceptance.

Refusal of final approval

5. Nothing in this Scheme shall prevent the Participating Authority whose approval or acceptance has been requested from refusing final approval to or acceptance of any ships' equipment tested and inspected under this Scheme if it has reason to believe that such equipment is not in conformity with its regulations. Refusal of final approval or acceptance and the reasons therefore shall be notified, without undue delay, to the Participating Authority which has carried out the operations referred to in paragraph 3 above.

Participation by other authorities 

  

 6.  (a)  This Scheme is open for participation by an administration  

          in another country which is competent to approve or accept  

          ships' equipment in relation to national regulations  

          (requesting authority). Requests for participation  

          expressing willingness to accept this Scheme, together with  

          a description of the regulations governing approval of  

          designs and specifications, inspections and tests, shall be  

          addressed to the Secretary-General of EFTA who shall notify  

          this to all Participating Authorities.  

          (i)  If the requesting authority is situated in a  

               contracting party to the GATT, its participation in  

               this Scheme shall take effect three months after the  

               request has been received by the Secretary-General.  

          (ii) If the requesting authority is not situated in a  

               contracting party to the GATT, its participation in  

               this Scheme requires the consent of all Participating  

               Authorities. The notification of consent shall be  

               transmitted to the Secretary-General through the  

               respective Ministry of Foreign Affairs. The  

               participation shall take effect three months after the  

               Secretary-General has received notification of consent  

               from all the Participating Authorities.  

          (iii) The date on which the participation in the Scheme  

               takes effect in relation to the requesting authority  

               shall be notified by the Secretary-General to all  

               Participating Authorities and the requesting authority.  

     (b)  A Participating Authority may, having regard solely to the  

          technical competence and reliability of the requesting  

          authority, notify the Secretary-General within two months  

          after this participation became effective, that it will not  

          accept the tests carried out by the requesting authority or  

          specify the conditions under which it will accept their  

          tests. The absence of such notification shall not prejudice  

          any of the rights of the Participating Authorities provided  

          for under this Scheme. Should the content of any such  

          notification be considered unsatisfactory by the requesting  

          authority it shall be free to withdraw from the Scheme with  

          immediate effect.  

     (c)  The Secretary-General shall amend the Appendix in accordance  

          with notifications received and forward them to all  

          Participating Authorities.

Amendments

7. This Scheme may be amended by mutual agreement between the Participating Authorities.

Consultations between Participating Authorities

8. Representatives of the Participating Authorities shall meet from time to time to discuss matters of common interest relating to the operation of this Scheme.

9. Such meetings shall be convened by the Secretary-General of EFTA whenever necessary, but at least once a year or upon request in writing indicating the reason for the meeting from two or more Participating Authorities in different countries.

Establishment of common requirements

10. In order to facilitate the application of this Scheme Participating Authorities may establish common requirements for items of ships' equipment.

11. A common requirement shall not preclude a Participating Authority from having other requirements additional to the provisions therein. Common requirements may be amended by general agreement of the Participating Authorities concerned.

12. A Participating Authority may at any time withdraw from a common requirement by notification to the Secretary-general. Any Participating Authority wishing to withdraw shall whenever practicable give reasonable notice to the other Participating Authorities of its intention to do so. The common requirement shall continue to apply as between those Participating Authorities which have not withdrawn from it.

13. The Secretary-General shall notify all Participating Authorities of the common requirements as well as of any amendments and withdrawals, and, from time to time, circulate a list of the requirements so far issued.

Withdrawal

14. A Participating Authority may withdraw from this Scheme by giving six months' notice in writing to the Secretary-General, who shall notify all other Participating Authorities. On withdrawal of a Participating Authority the Secretary-General shall revise the Appendix and circulate it to each Participating Authority.

           COMMON REQUIREMENTS FOR HYDROSTATIC RELEASE UNITS  

                   In force as from 1 September 1986

N.B.

These common requirements are to be read in connection with the text of the Scheme, as revised. Particular attention should be given to paragraph 11 of the Scheme. The reader is advised to ask the relevant Participating Authority if there are any national requirements additional to the provisions of these common requirements.

1. REQUIREMENTS

A hydrostatic release unit used in float-free arrangements shall: 

  

     1.1  be constructed with proper workmanship and materials;  

     1.2  not be damaged in stowage throughout the air temperature  

          range - 30 degrees C to + 65 degrees C;  

     1.3  be capable of operating satisfactorily throughout the  

          sea-water temperature range -1 degrees C to + 30 degrees C;  

     1.4  be rot-proof, corrosion-resistant, and not be unduly  

          affected by sea-water, oil or fungal attack;  

     1.5  where exposed to sunlight, be resistant to deterioration;  

     1.6  be constructed of compatible materials so as to prevent  

          malfunction af the unit. Galvanizing or other forms of  

          metallic coating on parts of the hydrostatic release unit  

          shall not be accepted;  

     1.7  automatically release the liferaft at a depth of not more  

          than 4 m;  

     1.8  have drains to prevent the accumulation of water in the  

          hydrostatic unit when the unit is in its normal position;  

     1.9  be so constructed as to prevent release when seas wash over  

          the unit;  

     1.10 be permanently marked on its exterior with its type and  

          serial number; date of manufacture, month and year;  

     1.11 be provided with a document or identification plate stating  

          the date of manufacture, type and serial number;  

     1.12 be fitted with a small plate permanently attached to the  

          unit on which the date when it was last seviced or, in the  

          case of a disposable unit the date when fitted, can be  

          recorded;  

     1.13 be such that each part connected to the painter system has a  

          strength of not less than that required for the painter;  

     1.14 be tested in accordance with section 2 below.  

     1.15 be constructed so that it can be readily removed for  

          servicing or replacment.  

 2.   PROTOTYPE TESTS  

     2.1  Two samples of hydrostatic release units shall be given a  

          visual and dimensional examination. If the devices conform  

          with the manufacturer's drawings and specifications, they  

          shall be accepted and assembled for further testing under  

          the technical and performance tests as prescribed in  

          paragraphs 2.2 and 2.3.  

     2.2   Technical tests  

          Each hydrostatic release unit shall undergo all the  

          following technical tests. No parts shall be renewed or  

          repaired between the tests. The tests shall be conducted in  

          the following sequence:  

          2.2.1  Corrosion resistance test  

                The hydrostatic release unit shall be exposed to a  

                salt water spray test (20 % natrium chloride solution)  

                at a temperature of +35 degrees C +/- 3 degrees for  

                160 h without interruption. After completion the  

                hydrostatic release unit shall show no corrosion which  

                could affect its efficient functioning and shall then  

                be subjected to the following tests after which it  

                shall continue to function efficiently.  

          2.2.2  Temperature tests  

                The hydrostatic release unit shall then be subjected  

                to the temperature cycling test prescribed in  

                paragraph 2.4.  

          2.2.3  Submergence and manual release tests  

                The hydrostatic release unit shall then be tested by  

                applying a buoyant load equal to its designed capacity  

                while the device is submerged in water or in a  

                water-filled pressure testing tank. It shall release  

                at a depth of not more than 4 m. On completion of  

                these tests and resetting, the hydrostatic release  

                unit shall be capable of being released manually if it  

                is designed to allow manual release of the unit. It  

                shall then be opened for inspection and shall show no  

                significant signs of corrosion or degradation.  

          2.2.4  Strength test  

                After reassembly the hydrostatic release unit shall be  

                subjected to a tensile test of at least 10 kN and, if  

                designed to allow manual release of the unit, shall  

                then be capable of being operated manually.  

          2.2.5  Technical tests on the membrane  

                The following tests shall be carried out on the  

                membrane:  

            (a)  Test of resistance to cold  

                Number of specimens     2 membranes  

                Temperature             - 30 degrees C  

                Exposure time           30 min  

                Flex testing            180 degrees with both  

                                        inside and outside  

                                        stretched.  

                 Requirements:  

                The membranes shall show no visible cracking.  

            (b)  Test of resistance to heat  

                Number of specimens     2 membranes  

                Temperature             + 65 degrees C  

                Exposure time           7 days  

                 Requirements:  

                The membranes shall show no visible cracking.  

            (c)  Test for surface resistance to oil  

                Number of specimens     2 membranes  

                Temperature             + 18 degrees C to 20 degrees C  

                Type of oil             A mineral oil  

                                        meeting the  

                                        following  

                                        requirements:  

                                        Aniline point: 120 degrees  

                                        +/- 5 degrees C  

                                        Flashpoint: minimum  

                                        240 degrees C  

                                        Viscosity: 10-25 cSt  

                                        at 99.0 degrees C  

                The following oils may be used:  

                                        ASTM Oil No. 1  

                                        ASTM Oil No. 5  

                                        ISO Oil No. 1  

                Testing period          3 h on each side  

                Requirements:  

                The material shall show no deterioration.  

            (d)  Resistance to sea-water  

                Two membranes shall be immersed for 7 days in 5%  

                natrium chloride solution.  

                Test temperature        + 18 degrees C to 20 degrees C  

                 Requirements:  

                The material shall show no deterioration.  

            (e)  Resistance to detergents  

                The membranes shall not be affected by detergents  

                commonly used on board ship.  

     2.3   Performance test  

          2.3.1 A liferaft shall be placed horizontally in a rack or  

                platform of sufficient weight to submerge the  

                liferaft. The hydrostatic release unit, the weak link  

                (when fitted) and the painter shall be installed as on  

                board ship.  

          2.3.2 The following tests shall be carried out in a suitable  

                depth of water. The platform on which the liferaft is  

                mounted shall be lowered into the water as follows:  

          2.3.2.1 horizontal;  

          2.3.2.2 tilted 45 degrees and then 100 degrees with the  

                  hydrostatic release unit at the upper side;  

          2.3.2.3 tilted 45 degrees and then 100 degrees with the  

                  hydrostatic release unit at the lower side;  

                  and  

          2.3.2.4 vertically.  

          Under these conditions the hydrostatic release unit shall  

          release the liferaft at a depth of not more than 4 m.  

     2.4   Temperature cycling test  

          The following test shall be carried out on two units:  

          The hydrostatic release units shall be alternately subjected  

          to surrounding temperatures of -30 degrees C and + 65  

          degrees C. These alternating cycles need not follow  

          immediately efter each other and the following procedure,  

          repeated for a total of 10 cycles, is acceptable:  

          2.4.1 an 8 h cycle at + 65 degrees C to be completed in one  

                day;  

          2.4.2 the specimens removed from the warm chamber that same  

                day and left exposed under ordinary room conditions  

                until the next day;  

          2.4.3 an 8 h cycle at -30 degrees C to be completed the next  

                day; and  

          2.4.4 the specimens removed from the cold chamber that same  

                day and left exposed under ordinary room conditions  

                until the next day.  

          2.4.5 The hydrostatic release unit shall show no sign of  

                loss of rigidity under high temperatures and, after  

                the tests, shall show no sign of damage such as  

                shrinking, cracking, swelling, dissolution or change  

                of mechanical qualities.

               COMMON REQUIREMENTS FOR DOUBLE COMPARTMENT  

                          INFLATABLE WORK VESTS  

                   In force as from 1 September 1986

N.B.

These common requirements are to be read in connection with the text of the Scheme, as revised. Particular attention should be given to paragraph 11 of the Scheme. The reader is advised to ask the relevant Participating Authority if there are any national requirements additional to the provisions of these common requirements.

1. GENERAL 

  

    This specification applies to inflatable work vests constructed  

        with two inflatable buoyancy chambers of approved material,  

        inflating arrangement, protective cover and securing  

        arrangement.  

    1.1 A double compartment inflatable work vest consists of:  

        - a buoyancy chamber I with water-activated CO2 inflation,  

          manually activated CO2 inflation and oral inflation,  

        - a buoyancy chamber II with, as a minimum, means for oral  

          inflation,  

        - a neck opening,  

        - an adjustable securing arrangement,  

        - a protective cover for the deflated buoyancy chambers when  

          the work vest is worn uninflated, and  

        - audible and visual means for detection.  

    1.2 If only buoyancy chamber I is provided with CO2 inflation it  

        shall provide 155N of buoyancy in fresh water within 10  

        seconds of being submerged in water. If both buoyancy chambers  

        are provided with CO2 inflation they shall together provide at  

        least 155N of buoyancy within 10 seconds of being submerged in  

        water and each buoyancy chamber alone shall be capable of  

        providing at least 155N of buoyancy after oral topping up.  

        The work vest shall, when conditioned to the lowest  

        temperature at which the work vest is designed to be worn,  

        have completely opened its cover and be inflated to at least  

        67% of its specified volume within 10 seconds, after being  

        submerged in seawater at - 1 degrees C.  

    1.3 The buoyancy should not be reduced by more than 5% after 24  

        hours submersion in fresh water.  

    1.4 An inflated buoyancy chamber shall be so designed that an  

        unconscious or exhausted person will be supported with the  

        body inclined backwards with a mouth freeboard of at least 120  

        mm.  

    1.5 When inflated, buoyancy chamber II shall fulfil the same  

        requirements as buoyancy chamber I.  

    1.6 It shall be possible for a person in the water to inflate a  

        buoyancy chamber orally.  

 2.  MATERIALS FOR WORK VEST (BUOYANCY CHAMBERS), PROTECTIVE COVER AND  

     SECURING ARRANGEMENTS  

    2.1  General  

        2.1.1 Materials shall be of a type which satisfies the  

              Participating Authority. Tests shall be carried out on  

              samples of materials and components as supplied for use  

              in the manufacture of the inflatable work vest, and as  

              far as practicable in the form in which it is intended  

              that they shall be incorporated. When required by a  

              Participating Authority a fire test shall be carried out  

              on the completed work vest in accordance with IMO  

              Assembly resolution A. 521 (13) »Recommendation on  

              testing of life-saving appliances«.  

        2.1.2 Materials which will be exposed to the effects of  

              sunlight shall be resistant to exposure to ultraviolet  

              radiation. When the materials have been exposed to  

              light, minimum to class 5-6, in accordance with ISO  

              105-B02-1984 »Normal Condition«, the tensile strength  

              determined in accordance with British Standard BS 2576:  

              1977 and tested with the testing machine as mentioned in  

              Annex A, A2, shall be not less than 0.5 kN/50 mm. If the  

              fabrics are coated or proofed the tensile strength shall  

              be determined as stated in paragraph 2.2.1.  

        2.1.3 The material for the exterior of the buoyancy chambers  

              and for the protective cover shall be of a highly  

              visible colour (for example traffic yellow in accordance  

              with British Standard BS 381, ref. 368 or international  

              orange in accordance with British Standard BS 381, ref.  

              592).  

        Colour fastness:  

              (a)  The resistance to exposure to light when tested in  

                   accordance with ISO 105-B02-1984 »Normal  

                   Condition«, shall be not less than class 5.  

              (b)  The resistance to rubbing off when tested in  

                   accordance with ISO 105-x12-1984 dry and wet  

                   rubbing, shall be not less than class 3.  

              (c)  The resistance to sea water when tested in  

                   accordance with ISO 105-E02-1978 shall be not less  

                   than class 4.  

        2.1.4 The materials shall be inherently rot-proof, durable,  

              resistant to moisture and able to withstand normal wear  

              and stowage conditions.  

        2.1.5 The materials shall be able to resist temperatures  

              between -30 degrees C and +65 degrees C and shall be  

              capable of being folded at -30 degrees C without being  

              damaged.  

        2.1.6 The materials shall be resistant to salt water, oil and  

              oil products. They shall be tested in accordance with  

              SIS 882221 item 7.  

        2.1.7 The metal parts shall be resistant to corrosion. They  

              shall be tested in accordance with British Standard BS  

              1391: 1952, part 2. After 100 hours there must be no  

              sign of corrosion.  

    2.2  Buoyancy chambers  

        2.2.1 Material used for buoyancy chambers shall in addition to  

              the requirements of paragraph 2.1 comply with the  

              following:  

              - Tensile strength of at least 1.5 kN/50 mm (warp and  

                weft) when tested in accordance  with British Standard  

                BS 3424: 1982, part 4, using a constant rate of  

                traverse machine. (The test report shall additionally  

                state the breaking strength in each direction of the  

                test specimens.)  

              - Tear strength of at least 75 N (warp and weft) when  

                tested in accordance with British Standard BS 3424:  

                1982, part 5, Method 7A, or in accordance with DIN  

                53356.  

              - Puncture pressure of at least 20 N when tested in  

                accordance with SIS 882221.  

        2.2.2 The buoyancy chambers shall be able to withstand a  

              pressure of 3 N/cm2 (30 kPa) above atmospheric pressure  

              for 24 hours and also the overpressure caused by  

              releasing the CO2 inflation system after the vest has  

              bee inflated to a pressure of 1 N/cm2 (10 kPa) above  

              atmospheric pressure. The chambers shall also be capable  

              of withstanding a pressure of N/cm2 (100 kPa) for 1  

              minute.  

    2.3  Protective cover  

              Material used for the protective cover shall in addition  

              to the requirements of paragraph 2.1 comply with the  

              following:  

              - Tensile strength of at least 250 N/50 mm (warp and  

                weft) when tested in accordance with British Standard  

                BS 3424: 1982, part 4, using a constant rate of  

                traverse machine, if a coated or proofed material, and  

                when tested in accordance with British Standard BS  

                2576: 1977 using the testing machine mentioned in  

                Annex A of that standard if not a coated or proofed  

                material.  

              - Tear strength of at least 200 N (warp and weft) when  

                tested in accordance with British Standard BS 3424:  

                1982, part 5, Method 7A, if a coated or proofed  

                material and when tested in accordance with British  

                Standard BS 4F 100: 1982 if not a coated or proofed  

                material.  

    2.4  Securing Arrangement  

                Material used for the securing arrangement shall in  

                addition to the requirements of paragraph 2.1 have a  

                breaking strength of 1.5 kN.  

 3.  CONSTRUCTION  

    3.1  Work vest (buoyancy chambers)  

        An inflatable work vest shall be of such construction and  

        shape that:  

        3.1.1 an inflated buoyancy chamber does not restrict arm  

              movements when swimming, and such that it does not cause  

              discomfort by pressing against throat and chin,  

        3.1.2 the collar does not unduly restrict movement of the head  

              and reduce the field of vision,  

        3.1.3 an inflated buoyancy chamber remains fastened correctly  

              on the person wearing it in the water whether swimming  

              or floating in a reclining position regardless of the  

              size of an adult person wearing the vest,  

        3.1.4 it cannot be dislodged upwards over the head of a person  

              wearing it, when inflated, whether swimming or floating  

              in a reclining position,  

        3.1.5 it does not cause undue pressure whether inflated or  

              deflated against neck, throat or head when the person  

              wearing it jumps into the water,  

        3.1.6 the risk of the vest being dislodged over the head of a  

              person wearing it, whether inflated or uninflated, when  

              jumping into the water from a height og 4.5 m, is  

              negligible,  

        3.1.7 CO2 or air cannot be released inadvertently through  

              either the automatic CO2 or oral inflation system or the  

              deflation device,  

        3.1.8 seams shall be to the satisfaction of the Participating  

              Authority.  

    3.2  Comfort/mobility  

        An inflatable work vest shall be of such construction and  

        shape that:  

        3.2.1 when worn uninflated it fits comfortably, does not  

              restrict movements of arms, body and head, does not  

              reduce the field of vision and can be worn during work  

              on board without inconvenience as regards comfort and  

              mobility,  

        3.2.2 when worn with either of the buoyancy chambers inflated  

              it does not unduly restrict movements of arms, body and  

              head, does not reduce the normal field of vision, and  

              when worn on board ship and in survival craft does not  

              unduly impair the comfort and mobility of the person  

              wearing it,  

        3.2.3 when one or both of the buoyancy chambers are inflated  

              they do not exert an uncomfortable pressure against the  

              throat when the person wearing it is swimming or  

              floating in a reclining position,  

        3.2.4 the buoyancy of each chamber is arranged in such a  

              manner that when one or both buoyancy chambers are  

              inflated, the head of an unconscious or exhausted person  

              is supported backwards and sideways when the person  

              wearing the vest is in a reclining upright position.  

    3.3        Protective cover and securing arrangement  

        3.3.1 The protective cover shall provide for simplified  

              packing and the rear portion shall be attached to the  

              work vest in an easily detachable manner.  

              Joining and closing of the cover shall be effected in a  

              simple and safe manner, by velcrotapes, press buttons or  

              equivalent methods.  

        3.3.2 An inflatable work vest shall have an approved securing  

              arrangement which can be readily fastened, tightened and  

              released by one person without assistance.  

              The arrangement shall be such that:  

              - the work vest remains in its correct position when the  

                person wearing it jumps into the water or is swimming,  

              - it cannot cause injury to the wearer when the vest is  

                worn during work or in an emergency situation.  

        3.3.3 Straps resting against the body of the wearer shall have  

              a width of at least 25 mm.  

        3.3.4 The complete securing arrangement shall have a breaking  

              strength of at least 1.5 kN.

4. ATTACHMENTS An inflatable work vest may have a buoyant grab line attached with a simple handhold. The line shall have a length of not less than 1 m and a breaking strength of at least 1.5 kN.

5. MEANS FOR DETECTION 

  

    5.1 The inflated buoyancy chamber shall on the outside have at  

        least six readily visible areas (5 x 10 cm) of a suitable  

        retro-reflective material of an approved type which shall be  

        placed as high on the work vest as possible.  

    5.2 The work vest shall be fitted with a whistle firmly secured to  

        the vest by a cord of suitable lenght and stowed in a suitably  

        placed pocket. The whistle shall be of non-metallic material  

        and must not be adversely affected by water or humidity.

6. MARKING ARRANGEMENTS An inflatable work vest shall be clearly and permanently marked with the temperature range for which it has been tested, the name of the manufacturer or his trade mark, the name under which the vest is sold, the year of manufacture, and a mark showing by which Participating Authority it has been approved. A panel or other means on which can be marked the date and location of each inspection and servicing shall be attached in the vest.

7. PACKING It shall be possible to pack an inflatable work vest in the protective cover without restricting inflation of the buoyancy chambers. The packing shall be such that: - the work vest has as few folds as practicable, - all hard components which could damage the vest are placed in such a manner that the risk of wear during stowage and use of the work vest is minimized, - all hard components of the vest are protected by suitable shock absorbant material, and - the protective cover can be easily examined for external damage, and can be readily opened and closed for examination of the vest.

8. INSTRUCTIONS FOR USE AND INSPECTION 

  

    8.1 For each type of inflatable work vest approved instructions  

        for its use shall be available in the language or languages  

        required by the Participating Authority. At least the  

        following shall be included:  

        - donning and use of the work vest,  

        - operation of inflation equipment, replacement of parts and  

          maintenance of inflation equipment,  

        - maintenance and repairs of buoyancy chambers, and  

        - inspection of the work vest on board.  

    8.2 Inspection and servicing procedures, instructions and  

        maintenance manuals shall be to the satisfaction of the  

        Participating Authority.

9. PERFORMANCE TESTS The tests shall be carried out with at least six persons of the following heights and weights: 

  

     Height                       Weight  

    1.40 m - 1.60 m              1 person under 60 kg  

                                 1 person over 60 kg  

    1.60 m - 1.80 m              1 person under 70 kg  

                                 1 person over 70 kg  

    over 1.80 m                  1 person under 80 kg  

                                 1 person over 80 kg
Two of the persons shall be females. During the tests the persons shall wear underwear, boiler suit and shoes. 9.1 Righting An inflatable work vest shall in calm water keep an unconscious person in a safe upright position with the body inclined backwards with a mouth freeboard of at least 120 mm. The work vest shall be able, when inflated in the water, to turn, in not more than 5 seconds, the body of an unconscious person in the water from any unconstrained position to one where the mouth is clear of the water. 9.2 Swimming An inflatable work vest shall not unduly restrict swimming by breast- or backstroke. 9.3 Jumping It shall be demonstrated that when wearing a work vest and jumping into the water from a height of 4.5 m with either or both of the buoyancy chambers inflated or uninflated the wearer shall not be injured nor the work vest damaged.

10. PRODUCTION TESTS Each work vest should be proof tested by inflation to a pressure of 20.5 kPa for 1 minute. This should be followed by an airholding test at a pressure of 5 kPa for 15 minutes.

11. OTHER TESTS Other methods of testing the materials etc. will be accepted if it is proved to the satisfaction of the Participating Authority that the test results correspond to the requirements laid down.

12. RESERVATION AS TO APPROVAL Notwithstanding an inflatable work vest or the materials incorporated satisfying the requirements laid down in these common requirements, the Participating Authority may reject a work vest when it is found unfit for its purpose.

(* 1) Interpretation of Article 3 (agreed at the 15th Meeting of the Participating Authorities on 18 and 19 September 1985)

1. Article 3 of the Scheme for the reciprocal recognition of tests and inspections carried out on ships' equipment shall be interpreted as meaning that one Participating Authority shall examine designs and specifications for ships' equipment included in the Scheme submitted by another Participating Authority for approval or acceptance as meeting its national requirements.

2. Consideration shall be given to the use of the facilities of the Applying Authority to carry out inspections and tests where appropriate.

3. The approval or acceptance of items of ships' equipment in this way will have the effect that such equipment is acceptable for use on the ships of the Approving or Accepting Authority.

4. Approval or acceptance does not depend upon a particular ship or contract reguiring that equipment but is general.
